stem: A client is 24 hours post-total thyroidectomy. Based on the documentation in the Post-Surgical Parathyroid & Neuro Stability Log, which finding requires the most immediate intervention?

options.text: Administer IV calcium gluconate and initiate seizure precautions.
Assess the back of the neck for post-operative hematoma.
Encourage the client to eat high-dairy snacks.
Notify the physician of the 'Trousseau sign' and await further orders.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs of hypocalcemia (Trousseau's sign, circumoral paresthesia, low calcium level of 6.4 mg/dL) likely due to parathyroid gland damage during the thyroidectomy. This puts the client at high risk for laryngospasm and seizures. The most immediate intervention is to administer IV calcium gluconate and initiate seizure precautions to prevent life-threatening complications.
clinicalPearls: Trousseau's sign indicates hypocalcemia and is characterized by carpal spasm when a blood pressure cuff is inflated.
Chvostek's sign, another indicator of hypocalcemia, is characterized by facial twitching when the cheek is tapped.
After thyroid surgery, keep a tracheostomy tray and calcium gluconate at the bedside in case of complications.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing to check the neck first (a2) delays critical treatment.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While airway assessment is important, the presence of Trousseau's sign and a critically low calcium level indicate a metabolic emergency requiring immediate calcium replacement. Addressing the hypocalcemia is the priority.

mnemonic.title: T-T-T-C for Thyroidectomy Complications
mnemonic.expansion: T-Thyroidectomy, T-Tingling (circumoral paresthesia), T-Trousseau's sign, C-Calcium (administer IV calcium gluconate).

exhibits.title: Neuromuscular Exam
exhibits.content: Current: Client reports 'tingling' around the mouth (circumoral paresthesia). When the BP cuff is inflated to 20 mmHg above systolic pressure, the client's hand develops a carpal spasm (flexion of the wrist and adduction of the thumb).
